critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer are known for their distinctive white tails, which they raise when alerted to danger.
critters.activeFact: White-tailed deer can run up to 30 miles per hour to escape predators.
factHistory: White-tailed deer can run up to 30 miles per hour to escape predators.
White-tailed deer can run up to 30 miles per hour to escape predators.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears can climb trees quickly and are known to sleep in tree hollows for safety.
critters.activeFact: Black bears have excellent memories and can remember food sources for years!
factHistory: Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, nearly seven times better than a bloodhound.
Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, even better than bloodhounds!

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes typically travel in family groups but are also known to hunt solo when food is scarce.
critters.activeFact: Coyotes are highly adaptable and can live in deserts, forests, mountains, and even cities!
factHistory: Coyotes use high-pitched yips and howls to communicate and coordinate with their pack during hunts.
Coyotes can adapt to diverse habitats, including urban areas, making them highly versatile survivors.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes are highly adaptable and can thrive in diverse environments, from forests to urban areas.
critters.activeFact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and to keep warm during cold weather.
factHistory: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and to keep warm during cold weather.
Red foxes have excellent hearing, able to detect small animals digging underground.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes have a distinctive black stripe down their backs and long, bushy tails.
critters.activeFact: Gray foxes can climb trees, an unusual skill for members of the dog family!
factHistory: Gray foxes are unique canids that can climb trees to escape predators and find food.
Gray foxes are one of the few canids that can climb trees to escape predators.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats typically weigh between 15 to 35 pounds, depending on their habitat and available food sources.
critters.activeFact: Bobcats can leap up to 10 feet high, helping them catch prey and climb trees quickly!
factHistory: Bobcats have excellent night vision, aiding their hunting during nighttime or low-light conditions.
Bobcats can leap up to 10 feet high, making them excellent climbers and hunters.

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines are primarily herbivores, primarily feeding on leaves, bark, and fruit found in their forest habitats.
critters.activeFact: Porcupines have thousands of sharp quills that detach easily to protect them from predators.
factHistory: Porcupines' quills detach easily to deter predators, acting as a unique and effective natural defense.
Porcupines have up to 30,000 sharp quills for defense, which they cannot shoot but easily detach.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers have strong, chisel-like teeth that continuously grow, requiring constant chewing to keep them trimmed.
critters.activeFact: Beavers build dams to create ponds, helping protect their homes from predators and harsh weather.
factHistory: Beavers build dams using branches, mud, and rocks to create aquatic habitats for protection and food storage.
Beavers have transparent eyelids that allow them to see underwater while swimming.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats are excellent swimmers and can hold their breath for up to 20 minutes underwater.
critters.activeFact: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from vegetation, similar to beavers, but much smaller and cozier!
factHistory: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from vegetation, which protect them from predators and harsh weather.
Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from vegetation, often with underwater entrances for protection against predators.

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks have a thick, soft fur coat that helps them stay warm in cold, wet environments.
critters.activeFact: Minks have waterproof fur, helping them stay dry and warm while swimming underwater for food!
factHistory: Minks are excellent swimmers, using partially webbed feet to hunt fish and amphibians underwater.
Minks are semi-aquatic mammals skilled at swimming and hunting fish, small mammals, and birds.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers have a strong preference for mature forests, which provide ample cover and habitats for their prey.
critters.activeFact: Fishers are skilled climbers and can even chase prey up trees!
factHistory: Fishers are skilled climbers and use their agility to hunt prey like squirrels and birds.
Fishers are skilled climbers and use tree cavities for shelter and raising their young.

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can glide on their bellies down snowy slopes for fun, using their fur like a sled.
critters.activeFact: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to eight minutes while hunting fish.
factHistory: River otters can close their ears and nostrils underwater to stay submerged while hunting.
River otters have dense, water-repellent fur that keeps them warm and dry while swimming.

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can leap up to ten times their body length in a single jump while climbing.
critters.activeFact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can rotate their ankles 180 degrees to climb down trees headfirst!
factHistory: Eastern Gray Squirrels use their bushy tails for balance, communication, and warmth in cold weather.
Eastern Gray Squirrels can find food buried beneath a foot of snow using memory and smell.

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels can communicate using a variety of vocalizations, including alarm calls and chatter.
critters.activeFact: American Red Squirrels defend territories year-round, storing food in scattered caches called middens.
factHistory: American Red Squirrels are fierce defenders of their food caches, aggressively protecting them from intruders.
American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their food caches from intruders year-round.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks are primarily herbivorous, feeding on seeds, nuts, fruits, and occasionally insects or small invertebrates.
critters.activeFact: Chipmunks have cheek pouches that can expand to carry food back to their burrows for storage.
factHistory: Chipmunks have cheek pouches that can expand to carry food back to their burrows.
Chipmunks have cheek pouches that expand to carry food back to their burrows efficiently.

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe Hares have large, webbed feet that help them walk on top of the snow.
critters.activeFact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally, turning white in winter to blend with snow and brown in summer.
factHistory: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally for camouflage, turning white in winter and brown in summer.
Snowshoe Hares change fur color seasonally, turning white in winter to blend with snow and brown in summer.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails are crepuscular, being most active during dawn and dusk while foraging for food.
critters.activeFact: Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators!
factHistory: Eastern Cottontails use their strong hind legs to make quick, zigzag escapes from predators.
Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators.

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have a unique coat with a striking black and gray coloration, resembling a mask around their eyes.
critters.activeFact: Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws that help them identify objects by touch, even underwater!
factHistory: Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws that can remember how to open containers and solve puzzles.
Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws, allowing them to open containers and solve complex tasks.

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums have over 50 teeth, more than any other North American mammal.
critters.activeFact: Opossums play dead to avoid predators, slowing their heartbeat and breathing to appear lifeless.
factHistory: Opossums have a remarkable immune system that makes them resistant to many snake venoms.
Opossums are the only North American marsupials, carrying and nursing their babies in a pouch.

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks have excellent hearing and smell, aiding them in finding food like insects and small mammals.
critters.activeFact: Striped skunks can accurately spray their smelly liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators!
factHistory: Striped skunks can spray a powerful, foul-smelling liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators.
Striped skunks can accurately spray a foul-smelling liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels are primarily nocturnal and have large eyes that help them see in low light.
critters.activeFact: Flying squirrels glide by spreading a flap of skin called a patagium between their legs.
factHistory: Flying squirrels glide up to 150 feet using a flap of skin between their legs called a patagium.
Flying squirrels glide using a flap of skin called a patagium stretched between their limbs.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats can consume up to 1,200 insects in a single night, aiding in pest control.
critters.activeFact: Little Brown Bats can eat up to 1,000 mosquitoes in an hour‚Äînature‚Äôs own nighttime pest control!
factHistory: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to navigate and catch insects in complete darkness.
Little Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects mid-air with incredible precision and speed.

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats can live up to 30 years in the wild under ideal conditions.
critters.activeFact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, helping control mosquito populations naturally at night!
factHistory: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, consuming up to half their body weight nightly.
Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects mid-flight, consuming thousands each night.

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls mainly hunt at night, preying on small mammals, birds, and occasionally amphibians.
critters.activeFact: Barred Owls can mimic the calls of other birds to confuse their prey or rivals.
factHistory: Barred Owls have distinctive hoots that sound like "Who cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?"
Barred Owls have distinctive hooting calls that sound like "Who cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?"

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls are known for their distinctive hooting call, often described as a deep ‚Äúwhoo-hoo.‚Äù
critters.activeFact: Great Horned Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees without harming blood flow!
factHistory: Great Horned Owls have powerful talons that can crush prey bones, making them top nighttime hunters.
Great Horned Owls have ear tufts that help with camouflage and communication, not actual ears.

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays have strong, sharp beaks that allow them to crack open acorns and other tough nuts.
critters.activeFact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.
factHistory: Blue Jays can mimic the calls of hawks to scare away other birds from their territory.
Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds from feeders and territories.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are non-migratory and often stay in the same area year-round, even during harsh winters.
critters.activeFact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few birds where both males and females sing beautifully.
factHistory: Male Northern Cardinals sing to defend territory and attract mates, making their bright red plumage even more eye-catching.
Northern Cardinals are one of the few songbirds where males and females sing different songs.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees have a distinctive "chick-a-dee-dee-dee" call used to convey different messages and threats.
critters.activeFact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout the winter.
factHistory: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food during winter.
Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout winter.

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice have a distinctive crest on their heads, which enhances their visual appeal.
critters.activeFact: Tufted Titmice use their strong feet to cling upside down while searching for insects on tree bark!
factHistory: Tufted Titmice can mimic the calls of other birds to communicate or defend their territory.
Tufted Titmice often cache seeds to eat later, showing impressive memory skills in the wild.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches are known for their distinctive nasal "yank" call, which aids in communication with others.
critters.activeFact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike many other birds!
factHistory: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike most other birds.
White-breasted Nuthatches often climb down trees headfirst, unlike most birds that go upward only.

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers have a white patch on their backs that helps distinguish them from similar species.
critters.activeFact: Downy Woodpeckers are the smallest woodpeckers in North America, about the size of a sparrow!
factHistory: Downy Woodpeckers drum on trees to communicate and find insects hidden beneath the bark.
Downy Woodpeckers use their stiff tail feathers to brace themselves on tree trunks while pecking.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers have a unique white streak down their wings, helping to identify them in the wild.
critters.activeFact: Hairy Woodpeckers drum on trees to find insects, not just to communicate with other woodpeckers!
factHistory: Hairy Woodpeckers drum loudly to communicate and find insects hidden under tree bark.
Hairy Woodpeckers drum rapidly to communicate and establish territory in North American forests.

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers have a striking red crest that makes them one of North America's largest woodpeckers.
critters.activeFact: Pileated Woodpeckers can drill holes 3 inches wide to find insects hiding deep in trees!
factHistory: Pileated Woodpeckers create large rectangular holes in trees to find insects and build nests.
Pileated Woodpeckers create large rectangular holes in trees to find insects and build nests.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers primarily consume fruit and insects, rarely feeding on tree sap compared to other woodpecker species.
critters.activeFact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers have a strong, chisel-like beak to drill into tree bark for insects.
factHistory: Red-bellied Woodpeckers drum on trees to communicate and mark their territory.
Red-bellied Woodpeckers drum loudly to communicate and establish territory in their woodland habitats.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves produce a distinctive, mournful cooing sound that is often associated with their gentle nature.
critters.activeFact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour, making them surprisingly fast fliers!
factHistory: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour to evade predators.
Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour to escape predators and migrate long distances.

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches primarily eat seeds, with a preference for thistle and dandelion seeds.
critters.activeFact: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, changing from bright yellow in summer to duller feathers in winter!
factHistory: American Goldfinches molt twice yearly, changing bright yellow feathers in summer to duller olive winter plumage.
American Goldfinches molt twice yearly, changing their bright yellow feathers to olive-brown in winter.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos primarily forage on the ground, often dietary consisting of seeds and small insects.
critters.activeFact: Dark-eyed Juncos change feather colors seasonally, showing brighter plumage during breeding for attracting mates!
factHistory: Dark-eyed Juncos change plumage color seasonally, appearing brighter in winter for better camouflage in snow.
Dark-eyed Juncos change their song patterns regionally, creating unique local bird dialects across North America.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches often build their nests in close proximity to human habitation, utilizing structures like wreaths and lamps.
critters.activeFact: House Finches have red feathers on their heads, which actually come from pigments in the foods they eat!
factHistory: House Finches are native to the western U.S. but now thrive across much of North America.
House Finches are known for their cheerful, warbling songs used to attract mates and defend territory.

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches primarily eat seeds, but they also enjoy fruits and insects as part of their diet.
critters.activeFact: Purple Finches sing sweet, melodious songs that help them attract mates and mark their territory.
factHistory: Purple Finches have a distinctive raspberry red plumage that helps males attract mates during breeding season.
Purple Finches have a raspberry-red head and chest, making them easy to spot in North American forests.

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys have excellent vision, allowing them to see in full color and detect motion from afar.
critters.activeFact: Wild turkeys can fly at speeds up to 55 miles per hour for short bursts!
factHistory: Wild turkeys can fly short distances at speeds up to 55 miles per hour.
Wild turkeys can run up to 20 miles per hour and fly short distances at 55 miles per hour.

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse are known for their exceptional camouflage, blending seamlessly into forest environments with their feather patterns.
critters.activeFact: Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by beating their wing feathers to attract mates and mark territory.
factHistory: Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by beating air with their wings to attract mates.
Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by beating air with their wings to attract mates.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes can live up to 30 years in the wild.
critters.activeFact: Sandhill Cranes perform graceful, synchronized dances to strengthen pair bonds and communicate with each other.
factHistory: Sandhill Cranes perform synchronized dancing to strengthen pair bonds.
Sandhill Cranes perform intricate group dances involving bowing, jumping, and wing-flapping to communicate and bond.

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows are known for their problem-solving skills and can use tools to obtain food.
critters.activeFact: American Crows can recognize human faces and remember if someone is a threat for years.
factHistory: American Crows can recognize human faces and remember if a person is threatening or friendly.
American Crows can recognize human faces and remember those who pose threats.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens are highly intelligent and can use tools to help solve problems.
critters.activeFact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds, including human speech and animal calls, showing impressive intelligence.
factHistory: Common Ravens can mimic human speech and other sounds in their environment with surprising accuracy.
Common Ravens can mimic sounds from their environment, including human speech and animal calls.

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks can often be seen soaring on thermal updrafts, gaining altitude with minimal wing flapping.
critters.activeFact: Red-tailed Hawks can spot prey from over a mile away using their incredible eyesight!
factHistory: Red-tailed Hawks use their keen eyesight to spot prey from over a mile away during flight.
Red-tailed Hawks use their sharp vision to spot prey from over a mile away.

critters.name: Cooper‚Äôs Hawk
critters.fact: Cooper‚Äôs Hawks have sharp talons that help them grip and carry their prey effectively.
critters.activeFact: Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are skilled flyers that use surprise attacks to catch birds mid-air.
factHistory: Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are agile fliers, using quick twists to catch birds mid-air in dense forests.
Cooper‚Äôs Hawks are agile hunters, known for dashing through dense trees to catch small birds mid-flight.

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks often feed by dabbling, tipping their bodies underwater to reach food.
critters.activeFact: Mallard ducks can recognize and remember individual human faces for years.
factHistory: Mallard ducks can sleep with one eye open to stay alert for predators.
Mallard ducks are known for their distinctive green heads and loud quacking calls during mating season.

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks are known for their distinctive metallic-colored plumage and striking facial patterns.
critters.activeFact: Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities, making them unique among North American waterfowl species.
factHistory: Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities and are one of the most colorful North American waterfowl species.
Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities and their ducklings can jump from great heights safely after hatching.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese have distinctive honking calls, which they use to communicate during migration and to establish territory.
critters.activeFact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration, often forming a distinctive V-shaped flying pattern.
factHistory: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration using strong, graceful V-shaped formations.
Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration using a distinctive V-formation to conserve energy.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can stand still for long periods, blending into their surroundings to ambush prey effectively.
critters.activeFact: Great Blue Herons can fly at speeds up to 30 miles per hour while hunting for fish.
factHistory: Great Blue Herons use their long necks like a spear to catch fish with lightning-fast strikes.
Great Blue Herons use their sharp beaks to spear fish with lightning-fast precision.

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted Turtles are known for their vibrant colors, which can help them blend into their natural habitats.
critters.activeFact: Painted Turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, helping them stay submerged longer.
factHistory: Painted turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, helping them stay submerged longer.
Painted Turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, allowing extended dives.

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles can remain submerged underwater for several hours by slowing their heart rate significantly.
critters.activeFact: Snapping turtles have powerful jaws and can snap shut in less than a second to catch prey!
factHistory: Snapping turtles have powerful jaws strong enough to snap small bones and catch fish quickly.
Snapping turtles have powerful jaws that can snap shut with incredible force to catch prey.

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill are known for their distinctive black spot at the base of their dorsal fin.
critters.activeFact: Bluegill fish can hear sounds up to 1,600 Hz, helping them detect predators quickly underwater!
factHistory: Bluegill can breathe air by gulping surface air when oxygen levels in water are low.
Bluegill can breathe air through their skin in low-oxygen water conditions.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass are known for their strong fighting ability when hooked, making them popular among sport fishers.
critters.activeFact: Largemouth bass can grow over 2 feet long and use their big mouths to ambush prey!
factHistory: Largemouth bass can expand their jaws to swallow prey over half their own body length.
Largemouth bass can grow over 20 pounds and have a distinctive jaw that extends past their eyes.

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch can weigh up to 3 pounds and typically reach lengths of around 12 to 15 inches.
critters.activeFact: Yellow Perch have vibrant yellow bodies with dark vertical stripes, making them easy to spot underwater!
factHistory: Yellow Perch have bright yellow bodies with dark vertical stripes, making them easy to spot underwater.
Yellow Perch have distinct vertical stripes that help them blend into underwater vegetation.

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike can grow over four feet long and weigh more than 25 pounds.
critters.activeFact: Northern Pike can grow over 4 feet long and use sharp teeth to catch their prey swiftly!
factHistory: Northern Pike use ambush tactics, staying still before quickly striking prey with sharp teeth.
Northern Pike have sharp teeth and ambush prey using quick bursts of speed.

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers can change color slightly to match their environment, aiding in camouflage while hiding from predators.
critters.activeFact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched calls signaling early spring.
factHistory: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched peeping calls during early spring nights.
Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched calls that signal the start of spring.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs have a diet that includes insects, small fish, and even other frogs.
critters.activeFact: American Bullfrogs can grow up to 8 inches long, making them one of North America's largest frogs!
factHistory: American Bullfrogs can produce deep, loud calls that travel over half a mile to attract mates.
American Bullfrogs can produce deep, loud croaks that carry over long distances to attract mates.

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs have vibrant green or brown skin to blend into their aquatic habitats and avoid predation.
critters.activeFact: Green frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators quickly!
factHistory: Green frogs can produce a distinctive, banjo-like call heard during warm, rainy nights.
Green Frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to catch prey or escape predators.

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs are commonly found in wetlands, grasslands, and near streams throughout North America.
critters.activeFact: Leopard frogs get their name from their distinctive dark spots that look like a leopard‚Äôs coat.
factHistory: Leopard frogs have distinctive dark spots and are excellent jumpers, often leaping over 3 feet in a single bound.
Leopard frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators quickly.

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can vary in color, often displaying stripes or patterns that aid in camouflage.
critters.activeFact: Garter snakes can swim and often hunt amphibians in water, making them excellent swimmers!
factHistory: Garter snakes can detect chemicals in the environment using their forked tongues and Jacobson‚Äôs organ.
Garter snakes can swim and often hunt amphibians and fish in water.

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes are non-venomous and primarily rely on constriction to subdue their prey.
critters.activeFact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to two hours while hunting or hiding from predators!
factHistory: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to 20 minutes while hunting or hiding.
Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to 30 minutes while hunting.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes are proficient constrictors, subduing their prey by wrapping around it tightly.
critters.activeFact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes with similar coloring to avoid predators.
factHistory: Eastern Milk Snakes vibrate their tails like rattlesnakes to mimic dangerous snakes and avoid predators.
Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes with their colorful patterns to avoid predators.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies lay up to 400 eggs on milkweed plants during their breeding season.
critters.activeFact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles to Mexico each fall, one of nature‚Äôs greatest journeys!
factHistory: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles between Canada and Mexico each year.
Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles from North America to central Mexico each year.

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies are known for their vibrant colors, which can vary widely among different species.
critters.activeFact: Swallowtail butterflies have tail-like wing extensions that help confuse predators and avoid attacks.
factHistory: Swallowtail butterflies flutter with distinctive tail-like wing extensions that mimic bird feathers for protection.
Swallowtail butterflies use their tail-like wing extensions to confuse predators during flight.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies have large, multifaceted eyes that can detect motion better than almost any other insect.
critters.activeFact: Dragonflies can fly in six directions: up, down, forward, backward, left, and right!
factHistory: Dragonflies can fly up to 30 miles per hour, making them some of the fastest insects.
Dragonflies can fly up to 30 miles per hour, making them some of the fastest insects in the world.

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies have specialized eyes that allow them to see both forwards and backwards simultaneously.
critters.activeFact: Damselflies fold their wings back when resting, unlike dragonflies that keep wings open.
factHistory: Damselflies fold their wings along their body when resting, unlike dragonflies that keep them open.
Damselflies fold their wings neatly over their bodies when at rest, unlike dragonflies.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies are not true flies; they are winged beetles belonging to the family Lampyridae.
critters.activeFact: Fireflies use bioluminescence to attract mates, creating magical glowing light shows in warm summer nights!
factHistory: Fireflies use bioluminescent light to attract mates and communicate in the dark.
Fireflies use bioluminescence to communicate, especially for mating signals during warm summer nights.

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees can visit up to 2,000 flowers in a single day while foraging for nectar.
critters.activeFact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of tasty flowers with their hive friends!
factHistory: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of flowers with their hive mates.
Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of food sources with their hive mates.

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees are excellent pollinators and can pollinate plants that other bees cannot due to their size and strength.
critters.activeFact: Bumblebees can fly despite their small wings by beating them about 200 times per second!
factHistory: Bumblebees have hairy bodies that help them collect and transfer pollen between flowers efficiently.
Bumblebees can regulate their body temperature to fly in cold weather unlike most other bees.

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers produce sounds by rubbing their hind legs against their wings, a process known as stridulation.
critters.activeFact: Grasshoppers have powerful hind legs that can leap over 20 times their body length in a single jump!
factHistory: Grasshoppers can leap over 20 times their own body length in a single jump.
Grasshoppers can leap up to 20 times their body length using powerful hind legs.
